if posix_fallocate fails.

core-clocksource: add check to see if HPET clocksource is being used

The HPET clocksource impacts on performance benchmarking on x86 because
it takes thousands of clock cycles to complete and is way more expensive
than reading the TSC. When scaling to many CPUs and performing many
context switches we end up with bottlenecking on the HPET reads and this
impacts heavily on performance benchmarks. Add a pre and post stress
run check and throw a warning message if HPET clocksources are detected.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

stress-metamix: add a new stressor that exercises a mix of file metadata operations

Try to emulate a Lucern style of concurrent file based metadata exercising
operations on 16 files per stressor instance. Each stressor runs 16
concurrent processes that each exercise a file's metadata with sequences
of open, 256 lseeks and writes, fdatasync, close, fsync and then stat,
open, 256 lseeks, reads, occasional file memory mapping, close, unlink
and lstat.

As suggested by Dave Turner, https://github.com/ColinIanKing/stress-ng/issues/316

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

stress-epoll: silently ignore -ve parameter passed to epoll_wait

so silently ignore any gcc warnings. This silences up arm gcc 12.x
warnings.

core-log: change semantics of pr_lock/unlock

The lock/unlock was intended to stop intermingled writes from
different stressors occurring.  This used a spin lock which causes
a lot of locking contention when running many stressor instances and
this can add large run time delays when stressors rush to write
termination messages at the end of run. A better strategy is to
change the semantics of pr_lock/unlock to pr_block begin/end to
indicate where a block of writes should be written out atomically
with a single write call. The block begin starts buffering messages
and the block end flushes out the buffered messages in one large
write where possible. If buffers cannot be allocated we fall back
to single writes and break the block buffering.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

Manual: add more explanation why --log-lockess is useful

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

core-helper: Add 1 ms yielding in logging and fork child startup

Some older systems have a lot of latency in the main fork child startup
when there are a lot of cpu intensive stressors that don't yield in their
main loop. To allow stress-ng to rapidly fork off a lot of child processes
add a 1ms reschelding yield/sleep in each child immediately after they get
running. Also add a 1ms yield/sleep in the logging locking rather than
hammer on just short yields to make logging contention more yieldy when
hundreds of spawned child processes log start/stop messages.

Kudos to Zhiwei Chen at Intel for reporting and help in debugging this
issue.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

stress-vnni: verify if selected method supports intrinsic in intrisinc mode

On a Xeon 6140 with the following flags:
fpu vme de pse tsc msr pae mce cx8 apic sep mtrr pge mca cmov pat pse36

vpaddb method works:
$ stress-ng --metrics-brief --vnni-method vpaddb --vnni 1 --timeout 1
stress-ng: info:  [725846] setting to a 1 secs run per stressor
stress-ng: info:  [725846] dispatching hogs: 1 vnni
stress-ng: metrc: [725846] stressor       bogo ops real time  usr time  sys time   bogo ops/s     bogo ops/s
stress-ng: metrc: [725846]                           (secs)    (secs)    (secs)   (real time) (usr+sys time)
stress-ng: metrc: [725846] vnni             448081      1.01      0.99      0.02    442979.71      442911.78
stress-ng: metrc: [725846] miscellaneous metrics:
stress-ng: metrc: [725846] vnni           503335901.06 vpaddb ops per sec (geometric mean of 1 instances)
stress-ng: info:  [725846] skipped: 0
stress-ng: info:  [725846] passed: 1: vnni (1)
stress-ng: info:  [725846] failed: 0
stress-ng: info:  [725846] metrics untrustworthy: 0
stress-ng: info:  [725846] successful run completed in 1.01 secs

But not when asking for intrinsic-only mode:
$ stress-ng --metrics-brief --vnni-method vpaddb --vnni 1 --timeout 1 --vnni-intrinsic
stress-ng: info:  [725860] setting to a 1 secs run per stressor
stress-ng: info:  [725860] dispatching hogs: 1 vnni
stress-ng: metrc: [725860] stressor       bogo ops real time  usr time  sys time   bogo ops/s     bogo ops/s
stress-ng: metrc: [725860]                           (secs)    (secs)    (secs)   (real time) (usr+sys time)
stress-ng: metrc: [725860] vnni                  0      1.01      0.99      0.02         0.00           0.00
stress-ng: info:  [725860] skipped: 0
stress-ng: info:  [725860] passed: 1: vnni (1)
stress-ng: info:  [725860] failed: 0
stress-ng: info:  [725860] metrics untrustworthy: 0
stress-ng: info:  [725860] successful run completed in 1.01 secs

That's because the vpaddb method does not support intrinsic-only mode.
But it wasn't check before launch. This commit adds that check.

stress-pty: don't treat EINTR as failure when tcdrain is interrupted

The tcdrain() could be interrupted by signals, so in that case it
returns EINTR, but the signal stress-ng received could come from
SIGALRM, which was just set by timer. The best practice usually
implements retry mechanism but this commit can simply ignore EINTR.

this ends up with bottlenecking on the netfilter connection management so
bump the default to 10000 messages and make this parameter a run time option.

Manual: Indent stressors to ease man page reading

The current man page file is listing all stressors options in a single
and contiguous list.

It's difficult for readers to estimate what options is tied to which
stressor, especially when names are very similar like :
       --mmapfork N
       --mmapfork-ops N
       --mmapfixed N
       --mmapfixed-mlock
       --mmapfixed-ops N

It's not that easy to see there are two different stressors.

This patch is about identing all options tied to the same stressor under
a title explaining what the stressor is about.

In addition two little changes were done here:
	1/ --wait is moved after vnni stressor to keep alphabetical ordering
        2/ lower-level cache is renamed to last level cache

stress-ng: add new --with option to specify stressors to run with --seq or --all options

This allows one to specify a list of stressors that should be exercised rather
than using all of the stressors, e.g.

5 instances of cpu, hash, nop and vm stressors to be run one after each other, each
one runs for 1 minute:

	stress-ng --seq 5 --with cpu,hash,nop,vm --timeout 1m

32 instances of cpu, hash,nop and vm stressors to be run at the same time for
a total of 1 minute:

	stress-ng --all 32 --with cpu,hash,nop,vm --timeout 1m

stress-hdd: fix verification on partially completed writing due to ENOSPC

Verifiction will randomly fail when ENOSPC occurs and the writes are
not fully complete. The read pass will overcheck the size and will trigger
spurious and incorrect read verification failures. Fix this by keeping
track of the maximum successfully written amount of data and only read
as much as this back to verify.

Fixes: https://github.com/ColinIanKing/stress-ng/issues/305

stress-cache: fix the help of the --cache-size option

stress-cache: Add --cache-size option, set cache-size = N, and ignore --cache-level option

This commit adds the --cache-size option to the stress-cache tool.
The --cache-size option allows specifying a custom cache size in
bytes and overrides the --cache-level option.
This enhancement is particularly useful in scenarios where the cache
information is missing in the host machine's cache device tree.
It can be applied in the following situations:

1. When the 'lscpu' command does not display any cache information.
2. When the 'grep . /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu*/cache/index*/size'
command does not provide valid cache details.
3. When running on an ARM QEMU virtual machine.

By introducing this option, users can continue to perform cache stress
testing by providing a custom cache size even when the cache device
information is inaccessible. This allows for more flexibility and
support in various cache-related testing and simulation scenarios.

[Colin Ian King]
Use stress_get_uint64_byte() to allow one to specify the size with
b, k, g suffix for bytes (optional), KBytes, GBytes respectively.
Add option to manual. Remove .gitignore changes. Clean up indentation
on cache-size help info.

Signed-off-by: mingkwind <mingkwind@gmail.com>

stress-mlockmany: break large mlock/munlocks into smaller chunks

mlocking large sizes can take a while especially on devices with
slow backing store for swap. Break the mlocking into relatively small
chunks and check for stressor contination flags to provide a more
timely termination of stressor child processes.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

core-shim: add a shim wrapper for posix_fallocate for expedited allocations

With some file systems the libc posix_fallocate will write until
the file system is full or the fallocate is complete using repeated
pwrite or write calls and it's not interruptible. On slow file systems
this can take a very long time to complete and to the user it looks like
stress-ng has blocked forever. Add a shim to posix_fallocate that
fallocates in 1MB chunks and also checks for the stress continue flag
and bail out early with a non-POSIXly conforming EINTR return.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

stress-stream: ensure number of elements is a multiple of unroll size

If the number of elements is different from the loop unroll size then
some residual values don't get computed or checksumed leading to a checksum
verification error. Ensure n is always a multiple of the largest loop
unroll size of 8.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

stress-ng: speed up child termination by blocking signals and skip excessive free'ing

Child stressor termination can be improved by stopping any signals since we know we're
on a termination path so why service them. Also, don't free up various global heap
resources in the child as the heap will be destroyed on _exit and the time to free
individual objects is unneccessary.  Also, free'ing some resources (such as stressor
objects) is counter productive if we're in a signal context also traversing the
stressor list.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

stress-ng: add --change-cpu option for force child processes onto another CPU

In some client/server stressor cases it can or may be advantageous on some
systems to force the child process of the client/server pair onto a different
CPU from that of the parent. This new option uses scheduler affinity to try
and move the child process to any CPU other than that of the parent. The
caveat is that the scheduler at any time move the parent to the same CPU
as the child. We could try and prevent that, but that turns the main stress-ng
process management into a mini-scheduler and insanity follows.

stress-eigen: add Eigen 2d matrix stress cases

Eigen is a useful test case since it's used by many folk for matrix
computation, so it makes sense to exercise it. Currently this only
builds for gcc + g++ toolchains (not musl-gcc). Add in extra build
tests to see if we have the necessary build environment to build the
C++ eigen matrix ops. If we don't, fall back onto an empty C matrix ops
source.

We also need to link using g++ when building in Eigen code; or fall
back to the normal gcc or other C tool chain if the Eigen library
does not exist or we're not using gcc/g++.

stress-stream: enable verification with --verify option

In verification mode we compare previous computes with latest to
see if there any difference. The data is initialized on each verification
loop as we need to compare like with like on the initial conditions. In
non-verify mode, we re-initialize the data every 64 rounds as initialization
is expensive and we need to re-initialize every so often to avoid data
accumulation overflow creep.

core-nt-store.h: fix double precision nt store

double to a uint64_t. The contents of the double needs storing. Fortunately

the mempcy. We could do the store on a type-punned value, but this causes
pedantic warnings.

stress-cpu: Deduce waiting time in active cycle from idle time

stress-cpu with cpu-load option to generate partial load works as
following:

First a certain amount of stress code is executed (governed by the value
of cpu-load). When this phase is executed, the active cpu execution time
is computed, using the CLOCK_PROCESS_CPUTIME_ID clock which equates to
scheduler runtime of the current thread.

Second, the idle delay is computed proportionally to the active cpu
execution time:

`delay = (((100 - cpu_load) * (t2 - t1)) / (double)cpu_load)`

This works fine without contention. Let's assume a cpu-load of 40%, and
an active cpu execution of 0.4s, the idle time would be 0.6s and the
toal cycle time 1.0s which indeed corresponds to 40% load.

However, the idle time delay calculation currently ignores the possibility
that the active time may be scheduled out while running, if there are
other tasks in the runq competing for CPU run time.

Let's assume 50% of contention. In this case, the active cpu execution
time of the stress cycle remains 0.4s, but the wall clock time is now
0.8s instead of 0.4s, as for 50% of the time the CPU was executing some
other task. Since the delay computation ignores wall clock, a delay of
0.6s is still computed. Now the total wall clock time for running the
complete cycle is 0.8s + 0.6s = 1.4s, of which 0.4s is active load,
resulting in a load of 28%, below the 40% target.

To fix this problem, deduct the idle time during active cycle from the
idle delay calculation. The idle time during the active cycle is
obtained by subtracting the active time from the wall clock time.

Signed-off-by: Fernand Sieber <sieberf@amazon.com>

Add --stderr option, default output now to stdout

Due to a long historical decision, logging of messages went to stdout
because there were originally mainly errors. Overtime all logged messages
ended up being written to stderr which is not correct.  Default all log
output now to stdout and add a --stderr option to allow one to revert
back to the older default.  This effectively makes the --stdout option
a no-op, but lets leave it in to stop any breakage for users that may
still use this.

stress-urandom: fix corruption of neighbouring mmap'd page

The urandom stressor writes over the end of a writeable mmap'd page
to exercise a page overead, but this corrupts adjacent pages causing
the cacheline stressor to report a failure:

stress-ng  --cacheline 1 --urandom 24 -t 60 --verify
stress-ng: info:  [14517] setting to a 60 second run per stressor
stress-ng: info:  [14517] dispatching hogs: 1 cacheline, 24 urandom
stress-ng: info:  [14518] cacheline: to fully exercise a 64 byte cache line, 32 instances are required
stress-ng: fail:  [14518] cacheline: atomicinc method: cache line error in offset 0x0, expected 1c, got 4e

Fix this my mapping 2 pages and making the 2nd page read-only non-writeable.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

Add forced_killed_counter to indicate a child has been killed forcefully

There are times where a child process has to be killed forcefully and
in doing so we end up with a state flag indicating the counter was
not updated sanely.  Add a helper to indicate that we know we have force
killed the stressor child so any inconsistent flag state in the counter
is expected. This allows us to differentiate between kills (say by the
OOM killer) and those that are intentional.

Stash io uring context and keep track of it with user_data. This simplifies
the completion error handling. Perform completions at the end of a round
of submits. Add more duplicated submissions to pad out with more work.
Remove the xattr ops because the original stressor code is not correct
and it does not add much to the I/O stress paths.

core-resources: ensure resources are marked as free as soon as possible

Currently if stress_resources_allocate bails out (e.g. due to timeouts or
allocation limits hit) then not all of the resource fields are set and the
default allocated memzero'd values are used when free'ing the resources
later. This can be an issue when using resources (such as semaphore ids)
that may be legitimately zero. Fix this by ensuring all the fields are
set to a 'free' value as early as possible before the allocation loop
is executed.

Closes: https://github.com/ColinIanKing/stress-ng/pull/284

that needs to be restarted. For the malloc stressor it is useful to

and we want to abort prematurely with an error rather than a silent
restart.

stress-module: stress finit_module() and delete_module()

There are different ways to test loading modules:

  * modprobe calls
  * kernel module autoloader

To stress tests modprobe we can simply run modprobe in a loop. To stress
test the kernel module autoloader we can stress tests using the upstream
kernel tools/testing/selftests/kmod/kmod.sh. This ends up calling
modprobe in the end, and it has its own caps built-in to self protect
the kernel from too many requests at the same time. Today we cap that
at 50 max concurrent threads at a time.

The userspace modprobe call will also prevent calls if the same module
exists already.

You figured that might be enough to stop usersapce or even the kernel
from doing stupid things, but its not! See the issues reported by
David Hildenbrand on > 400 CPUs with KASAN enabled we get a shortage
of vmap space.

Although I have patches which are in the works which seem to fix this
issue it is pretty hard to reproduce an environment that has 400 CPUs
to stress test what that is like. And although current debugging seems
to indicate that the issue is actually the kernel ACPI driver uses
aliases and each CPU trying to load the same drivers; and although we
have patches in the pipeline to hopefully fix that too [2] -- we still
need a way to stress the hell out of finit_module() because clearly
evidence is showing we could blame either userspace *or* even kernel
for doing stupid things.

This stress-ng modules stressor is designed to help stress test the
finit_module() system call even if the module is already loaded, letting
us tests things which are hard to reproduce as well, things which
otherwise modprobe would pick up on small systems. We allow two methods
to stress test, one with a shared file descriptor, and another where we
call open prior to each finit_module().

Example uses:

sudo ./stress-ng --module 1 --module-name xfs
sudo ./stress-ng --module 1 --module-name xfs --module-sharedfd

The /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/modules.dep file is looked for and
once we find a module which matches your name we use that path.
Since we're not trying to replicate modprobe we don't load any
dependencies for you. Be sure to have them loaded before running
your stress tests.

We don't use libkmod as we don't want to bloat stress-ng, and because
we can provide a simpler parser to get our target module *once*.

[0] https://lore.kernel.org/all/20221013180518.217405-1-david@redhat.com/T/#u
[1] https://lkml.kernel.org/r/bb6e15e0-2831-6352-82c8-92648a29fb0b@redhat.com
[2] https://lkml.kernel.org/r/20230316151036.10181-1-petr.pavlu@suse.com

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

stress-vm: fix prime index accumulation overflow and speed up modulo

The index into the memory buffer is currently being accumulated and will
overflow the 64 bits at some point causing aliasing. Fix this by performing
a modulo on the index with the buffer sz using 1 or more size subtractions
rather than the more computationally complex modulo operators. This way
we never wrap the 64 bit value and remove the expensive % op.  Also start
the prime sized stride at least 4K larger than the sz to add more cache
misses for more L1/L2/L3 stress.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

stress-vm: compute a new prime that is larger than sz rather than use PRIME_64

The current PRIME_64 value aliases when using sizes of 491M causing multiple
hits on some bits and none on others. Instead of using PRIME_64, use a prime
that is always larger than sz. Each new cycle of the vm method will compute
a new prime that is larger than the previous value ensuring we perform
different sized strides around the vm buffer.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

to terminate.

stress-chown: don't prematurely finish stressors on ENOENT or ENOTDIR

The first stressor to get a SIGALRM tidies up and removes the file that
the multiple chmod instances are chmod'ing, so we get ENOENT/ENOTDIR
errors and the other instances can terminate before their run time is
complete. Since we're still accessing the file via an open file descriptor
it makes sense to keep on exercising on this until all the stressor
instances get a SIGALRM to allow them to run to completion.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

Makefile: introduce PRESERVE_CFLAGS build flag

The stress-ng Makefile includes many nice environment auto-detection
features to adjust compilation flags. This is very convenient in
many compilation use-cases. However, in some other specific cross
compilation environments, those automatic CFLAGS adjustments may
create compilation failures.

For example, commit c00e695ed5 added -fstack-protector-strong if the
compiler recognize the flag. In some situations, for example a gcc
toolchain based on uClibc-ng without stack-protector libssp
enabled, gcc will recognize the option. Then, the Makefile adds the
option to CFLAGS, and the compilation/link fails at link time with an
error like:

    /toolchain/arm-buildroot-linux-uclibcgnueabi/bin/ld: cannot find -lssp_nonshared: No such file or directory
    /toolchain/arm-buildroot-linux-uclibcgnueabi/bin/ld: cannot find -lssp: No such file or directory

stress-ng is included in the Buildroot build system [1] [2], which
supports many architectures and toolchain configurations. This build
system carefully controls its CFLAGS. In such a case, it is
preferable for a package to avoid changing compilation flags.

This patch introduces the PRESERVE_CFLAGS Makefile variable which will
disable those CFLAGS adjustments, if set to 1. The current build
behavior is preserved if unset.

[1] https://buildroot.org/
[2] https://git.buildroot.org/buildroot/tree/package/stress-ng?h=2022.11.1

Signed-off-by: Julien Olivain <ju.o@free.fr>

stress-regs: fix build on riscv32

RISC-V register test routine is using 64bit registers only.
When compiling on 32bit RISC-V, compilation fails with output:

    stress-regs.c: In function 'stress_regs_helper':
    stress-regs.c:485:27: error: register specified for 's1' isn't suitable for data type
      485 |         register uint64_t s1  __asm__("s1")  = v;
          |                           ^~
    stress-regs.c:495:27: error: register specified for 's11' isn't suitable for data type
      495 |         register uint64_t s11 __asm__("s11") = s1 ^ 0xa5a5a5a5a5a5a5a5ULL;
          |                           ^~~

This patch fix this issue by protecting the stress_regs_helper()
function with an additional test, to restrict to 64bit.

Signed-off-by: Julien Olivain <ju.o@free.fr>

stress-mmap: fix build with HAVE_SYSCALL or __NR_mmap2 is undefined

Commit afae500a added macro tests for defined(HAVE_SYSCALL) and
system call numbers.

More specifically, in stress-mmap.c, function mmap2_try() was defined
only if __NR_mmap2 is defined.  See:
https://github.com/ColinIanKing/stress-ng/commit/afae500a23b198b9df421ad0fd9270fcdf65c3fb#diff-ffb0db2473f6c5e1b93dd33bce389ee836671a628fff9f903d097733f7ddfc9c

This commit forgot to replicate the same test when the mmap2_try()
function is used later at:
https://github.com/ColinIanKing/stress-ng/blob/50f3ef2560e928c4694894be0bb652e663af5076/stress-mmap.c#L754

When HAVE_SYSCALL or __NR_mmap2 is undefined, compilation fails with:

    stress-mmap.c: In function 'stress_mmap':
    stress-mmap.c:809:31: error: 'mmap2_try' undeclared (first use in this function); did you mean 'mmap_prot'?
       context.mmap = (mmap_func_t)mmap2_try;
                                   ^~~~~~~~~
                                   mmap_prot
    stress-mmap.c:809:31: note: each undeclared identifier is reported only once for each function it appears in

This patch fixes this issue.

stress-qsort: add an alternative qsort implementation

The libc qsort implementation may change between versions of libc so make
comparisons simpler by adding in a optimized version of the J. L. Bentley
and M. D. McIlroy tuned for 32 bit integers. There is a new --qsort method
option to support the choice, however, libc qsort remains the default.

Also, don't resort data with char sort as this can cause data duplicates
and we need to avoid this. Instread bit flip some bits in the data for a
faster and consistent ordering re-mashing.

names and are never removed. This pollutes the user's TMPDIR (which may
not be a tmpfs) and could potentially allow an attacker to clobber
files using symlinks. Instead, use the actual files created by mktemp.

core-mwc: add stress_mwc*modn() functions for modulo'd range

There are numerous occasions in stress-ng where mwc results are being
modulo'd with a value to constrain the range. This however leads to
modulo bias and hence a non-uniform random number distribution. Fix
this by introducing modn helpers that perform the modulo without the
bias.  We scale the desired modulo to large size that fits into the
mwc type size and pick random values until they fit into the range
of 0..scaled_max - 1. Then we can take the modulo without any bias.

See https://research.kudelskisecurity.com/2020/07/28/the-definitive-guide-to-modulo-bias-and-how-to-avoid-it/

Kudos to Guilherme Janczak for spotting and reporting this issue.

Closes https://github.com/ColinIanKing/stress-ng/issues/252

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

core-shared-heap: add strdup for shared description metrics string

The description string is currently a 32 byte array for each instance
and each metric (even unused ones). This is potentially a large
allocation (16 x 32 x number of stressors x number of stressor instances).
We can reduce this by replacing the description array with a pointer
to either a literal string or dup'ing the string using a shared heap.
The dup pre-checks to see if the read-only string is already being used
and will re-use this rather an dup'ing previous existing duplicates.

stress-str: bundle wcs function args into a struct, improves run time

Passing so many arguments to the str test functions is a inefficient when
some of these args are not used in all the functions. Improve the code by
replacing the args with a single struct that has all the args bundled up.
This also removes the need to voidify unused args to avoid unused arg
warnings. Speeds up the code by a few percent too on x86.

stress-signest: disable alternative stack before unmap

The signest stressor allocates an alternative stack for nested signal
handler to avoid stack overflow. But it does not disable the
alternative stack before unmapping it. When the stressor receives a
signal after it release the stack, it will trigger segmentation fault.

This stressor allocates wide range of system resources to make a
relatively heavyweight parent. Then thousands of child processes

resources and forkheavy stressors.

The new typedef ensures that ftype is known as a type, even if FLOAT
itself does not denote a type.  This helps with efforts porting to
modern C, where all implicit ints are flagged for investigation.

functions.  Without this change, this test will then always fail, not
testing anything.

testing anything.

core-thermal-zone: fix the average temperature calculation

The accumulated value of each reading was not reset during
the average temperature calculation, causing the subsequent
temperatures (from another thermal zone) to consider the
previous temperatures, resulting in incorrect results.

Fix this by resetting the counter value before each average.

stress-fault: triple minor page faults using MADV_DONTNEED where available

Marking a page as MADV_DONTNEED with madvise increases the minor page fault
count, so use this to add more page faulting stress.

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

stress-tlb-shootdown: double TLB read/writes and misses

Exercise TLB read/writes and read/write misses more using MADV_DONTKEEP
on anonymous and file backed memory mappings. This effectively doubles
the TLB read/write + read/write miss rate. This is will make performance
regressions easier to detect such as the one reverted by Linux commit
0ba09b173387 ('Revert "mm: align larger anonymous mappings on THP boundaries"')

Signed-off-by: Colin Ian King <colin.i.king@gmail.com>

stress-x86cpuid: more cpuid method for cpu stressor and make new stressor

This stressor is more focused on exercising on instruction on one specific
architecture, so remove it from the more generic cpu stressor. Add metrics
to get some meaningful idea of the cpuid throughput with the 18 different
leaf types.

To improve the optimization, make the stress_x86_cpuid() helper function
an inlined function so it compiles down to 1 op code.

stress-far-branch: re-work mmap handling for 32 bit and improved random mmaps

Re-work the mmap'ing by adding two helpers, the first tries to do 32 bit
mmapings on x86-64 for 32 bit requested addresses otherwise to normal
mmaping. The second helper tries to check of the page is already mmap'd.
If the page cannot be mmap'd then try various random address for a fixed
mapping, falling back to a non-fixed mapping if those fail.

Finally, unroll the indirect jmp call loop to cause more stress on
the branch prediction logic.
